title: 114_hr3943
content: The Act titled "Physician Assistant Education Public Health Initiatives Act of 2015" allows for student loan repayment for physician assistants in faculty positions within physician assistant education programs. The Act allows the Secretary to enter contracts with eligible individuals who agree to serve as faculty in physician assistant education programs in exchange for up to $10,000 annually towards their educational loans, with a cap of $45,000 per individual. Eligible individuals must be U.S. citizens, nationals, or lawful permanent residents. The Act authorizes funding for eligible individuals in the U.S. to serve as faculty in physician assistant education programs in exchange for loan repayment up to $10,000 annually, with a maximum of $45,000 per individual. Eligible individuals must have a graduate-level physician assistant degree, commit to serving as faculty for at least 2 years, and hold a physician assistant license or be eligible for licensure. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of this section. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of this section for fiscal years 2017 through 2021. "Physician Assistant Primary Care Provider Loan Repayment is authorized for fiscal years 2017 through 2021." The Secretary will contract with eligible individuals to serve as physician assistants in underserved areas for at least 2 years in exchange for the Federal Government paying off their educational loans. Eligible amount refers to the principal and interest on educational loans outstanding at the start of the service. The program offers eligible individuals loan repayment in exchange for serving as physician assistants in underserved areas for at least 2 years. Eligible individuals must be U.S. citizens, have a graduate-level physician assistant degree, and have a contract with a healthcare provider in a shortage area or health center. Repayment amounts are 30% of principal and interest for the first two years and 25% for the third year of service. The program requires eligible individuals to serve as physician assistants in underserved areas for at least 2 years. It defines terms like 'health center', 'medically underserved area', and 'health professional shortage area'. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2017 through 2021. The effective date is upon enactment of the Act. SEC. 3 extends authorization of appropriations to support faculty development and disadvantaged students for fiscal years 2017 through 2021. SEC. 4 reauthorizes primary care training and enhancement programs. SEC. 4 reauthorizes primary care training and enhancement programs for fiscal years 2017 through 2021. SEC. 5 provides grants for research on physician assistant education. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide grants to eligible entities for research on physician assistant education. Entities must submit an application and award funds to support researchers each year. Recipients of the grant must report on the activities conducted using the funds. The eligible entity must submit a list of researchers affiliated with institutions, their research topics, citations to published research, evaluation of grant benefits, and any other requested information. An eligible entity is a non-profit organization with expertise in physician assistant education and faculty development. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of "eligible researcher," "physician assistant education," and "Secretary." It also mentions the authorization of appropriations. Authorization of appropriations is granted for fiscal years 2017 through 2021 to carry out the provisions of this section.
